author: Ozymandias_12
body:
There are better stocks in the semi conductor sector like AMAT, ASML, LRCX, KLIC, KLAC, UMC etc. that I would buy before I'd consider Intel. TSM and Samsung are both spending 100 billion each on fabs, and somehow Intel's 20 billion plus whatever subsidy they get from the US is suddenly gonna change everything?

The entire economic system can collapse and Intel will stay at the 40-60 range. Hell, even if the Sun expanded and half of Earth is disintegrated, Intel will stay in that range.

author: ysabeaublue
body: I love my boring LRCX right now, lol. Glad to have added a "shovel stock" in this chip/semiconductor space.

author: merlinsbeers

author: audaciousmonk
body:
Someone else showing LRCX some love!

Been making bank off their stock for 5+ years

author: seigy
body: My take is $TSM makes high-end chips for NVDA & AMD, $GFS makes a mix of chips, $UMC makes legacy chips (main thing we are currently short on), $INTC makes their own chips.  There are others but I think these are the big fabs and foundries.  I believe $QCOM, $AVGO, $SKWS, $TXN make their own and get some from fans but I am not certain on them.  Other plays to consider are the equipment mfg who make the equipment, parts, and services the fabs are buying in order to make more chips.  Some big players here are $AMAT, $ASML, & $LRCX.

author: EatsbeefRalph
body:
Where are they getting their fabrication equipment? 
Lam Research $LRCX might be the real play here.

author: vizk0sity
body:
tool suppliers. I personally hold AMAT, LAM RESEARCH, KLAC, TSM. You can add in more such as ASML, Tokyo Electron Limited. ASML has a monopoly on the EUV but they are limited by the supplier's capacity (you can't make as many as you'd like). This is the same as the TSM problem. One thing to remember, semiconductor is a cyclical business and won't go up forever. When oversupply/stockage happens, it will last for a few quarters. Most of these stocks will pull back. I don't expect them to have any oversupply until possibly at the earliest, late 2022 however. Watch the capex as usually that indicates expansion in the industry.

Fyi, I work for process dev. engineer in a fab for 6 years. If my opinion matters to you.

author: seigy
body:
Yep, for some reason people seem to be blind as to just how big the market is and how much money is being invested.  I posted this as part of an assessment of money flows in a different subreddit last weekend.  I have even read a few more semi investment plans since.   

Semiconductor fabs and foundries spending plans: 
Samsung $205B/3yrs, 
Micron $150B/10yrs, 
Intel $115B/3yrs, 
Taiwan Semi $100B/3yrs, 
United Micro $2B in 2022, 
SK Hynix $235B/10yrs. 
Major plays $LRCX, $ASML, $AMAT, $TER. 
Minor plays $NUE, $X, $CLF, $VMC, $FCX, $URI, $CAT.

My favorite quote I read this week that shows just this was from Pat Gelsinger: “I think I have more concrete trucks working for me today than any other human on the planet,” Gelsinger said. “We have construction in Oregon, New Mexico, Arizona, Ireland and Israel. And we expect to plant our next major fabs in the U.S. and Europe before the end of this year.”

author: 95Daphne
body:
While it has just been NVDA/AMD at times, since the Nasdaq bottomed on October 4th, there have been plenty of semiconductor stocks that have done really well:

AVGO: +18.6%

AMAT: +20.8%

(two holdings of mine)

LRCX: +23.7%

(was a holding of mine but I let myself get spooked about the way semis were running, I shouldn't have sold it)

MU: +22%

QCOM: +45%

While some of them have been bleh, most SOXX stocks look more like AVGO and AMAT than SWKS and QRVO, and it's a bit of an under the radar reason why the Nasdaq got back to a record and looked fine underneath until a couple weeks ago.

author: MinnesotaPower
body:
You're missing the fundamentals. AAPL has a monster net income and is the best of the 3 imo. TSLA has a razor thin margin, very little cash flow, and an insane amount of growth already priced in. Anyone should wonder if they're late to the party with TSLA. SOFI is also speculative but in a different way. It's not profitable at all (it's losing money) but has seen income growth in recent quarters (losing less than they used to).

I don't own any of these. Lots of companies have stronger fundamentals imo. Examples I own include GOOGL, V, LRCX, TGT, ADBE, NVDA, MU, IIPR. I also like MSFT, AMD, INTC, HIMX.

author: MinnesotaPower
body:
It is possible, yes. Of course it depends on the chip, and the company. This had essentially been the story of MU for a while. (Investors believed this is the best MU can get. So instead of getting rewarded on good earnings, the stock would go down because "how could it get any better than this?")

Of course, companies might be disciplined and avoid this situation entirely. 

Furthermore, if that's your theory, you can invest in equipment makers like LRCX and AMAT. They make the shit that makes the shit.

author: EMTPirate
body:
I checked your profile to see if you are another one of the Chinese profiles that keeps pushing junk investment, and I doubt a lawyer would need to buy a Turkish knockoff of a Glock, but I'll give you the benefit of the doubt that you are just a bad lawyer and can't afford anything better.

I know a good deal about China, I know about the power struggle between Xi Jinping and the Jiang Zemin faction that is causing a lot of these crackdowns. I know the Army swears allegiance to the CCP instead of the nation. That the CCP rules as the please from Zhongnanhai without regard to laws.  They are content to practice hostage diplomacy like they did with the two Michael's to free Meng Wanzhou and they seem confused when western counties can't simply disregard the courts and do as they please like China. That the Belt and Road initiative is just neo colonialism to steal resources and strategic ports from poor nations. That the Uighurs face slave labor and genocide by controlling birth rates and harvesting organs like Falun Gong practitioners. 

China is not a free, fair, or open market. Ask Jack Ma who got disappeared by them. Look at their national security laws, and how they annex neighborhoods and force their will on them. How they alter maps and globes to include the 9 dash line and pretend it is part of Chinese territory like the Scarborough shoal despite court rulings.

So tell me how elections matter when China can decide who is on the ballot to prevent a true opposition and use the national security law to disappear opposition?

Call me a typical American, but my eyes are open to the actions of the CCP.

author: EtadanikM
body:
You are all sorts of stupid if you think this wasn't caused by people like Jack Ma. It was precisely corporate greed that caused Chinese real estate companies to operate pyramid schemes where they would use the down payments from apartments that weren't even built to finish previous apartments that weren't even built. Ant Group would've made this infinitely worse with its "wild west" loan shark practices. Run away financialization IS the cause of over building.

This is a problem that Deng and his successors created. It isn't new.

author: moaiii
body:
That doesn't work well with options most of the time due to gamma. You could have a fairly small pullback of the underlying down to a support line or MA which will knock 50% or more off the premium almost instantly. You close, because you couldn't get a fill at 20% down, but then the underlying confirms support and shoots right back up again past your entry point bringing those premiums straight back up with them. You just lost over 50% when the trade was always above support, still trending up, and doing just fine.

Trade on the price action, not the P&L, assume that the cost/margin to enter the trade is your "at risk" amount, and set your position size accordingly.

author: LuxGang
body:
Someone yesterday made a great post analysing the Fintech companies like V, MA, PYPL, SQ etc.

The point this user made boils down to:

V, MA, SQ, PYPL etc still have inflated P/E ratios(30+), while companies like GOOG are trading below 30 P/E and growing faster. So why buy an overpriced Fintech when you can buy GOOG at a much better value?

Makes sense to me. I was looking at buying one of the aforementioned stocks, but now I think I'll just stick to big tech, which to me looks like a much better long term buy. Thoughts?

author: SmallParade
body:
>43.5 payment transactions per active account on a trailing twelve months basis, growing 11%

That’s from PayPal’s last earnings report. People are using it 3.6 times a month on average. That’s about how often I use it. I don’t use cash much anymore either but I use it more than 3.6 times a month. And I use my debit MasterCard to pay from my bank account probably 60-100 times a month. You understand now why they wanted to buy Pinterest. Generally speaking, people aren’t going around flashing the PayPal app everyday to pay for things. They use it here and there.

body:
I’ve said it before and I’ll say it again-

Gambling is why we are here. But when you gamble you know the odds and the rules of the game. (Mostly- I still don’t understand craps but I’ll lose money on it anyway)

Point is this- don’t fuck around with Chinese stocks.  They have no rules. The Chinese government is also instituting some new Jack Ma rules to keep companies from getting too strong. A Chinese company gets too big and the government will knock it down. 

Don’t fuck around with Chinese stocks.  (And you aren’t even really buying their stocks since foreigners can’t own Chinese stock directly). 

You’re buying promise rings from virgins who haven’t figured out their sexuality while their ultra religious father tries to send them to straight camp.

author: duskick
body: To me, SQ is an earlier version of PayPal.  They are in the process of creating their network.  The benefit they have in the long run in owning the hardware, software, and network, is that they can eliminate Visa and MasterCard from the equation.  If someone uses the Cash app to buy directly from a SQ terminal, the could reduce the charge from 2-3% (of which they get a small cut) to 0-5-1% (of which they get all).  SQ wins, merchant wins, but V and MC lose on such a transaction. PayPal is trying to build a similar network, but doesn’t have as much traction with in person terminals.

author: phohunna
body:
I live in Canada and I recently visited friends in MA where weed was legalized in 2017. Many municipalities still ban the sale.

In Boston, they have like 2 recreational dispensaries for the entire city. We had to bike nearly a half hour from Cambridge, and there were several security guards for the sleepy store. You can't buy with a credit card because the lending banks want nothing to do with it.

In Canada by contrast, its much more like a small fancy liquor store. We have dispensaries every few blocks and zero security guards. You can go in and buy with your credit card.

Companies like TLRY wont take off until there is sufficient distribution and its easy to buy. That wont come until its nationally legalized. Its going to be a long time.

author: MungerMentalModel
body: if you go to [tradingview.com](https://tradingview.com), go to the chart, click on "indicators" , then search for "MA".  add it to the chart and then you can change the settings for it to show 20 instead of the default which is 9.  The price action of a stock frequently interacts with the moving average, the moving average acts like a rubber band.  The farther the stock moves away from it, the stronger it wants to rebound back.

author: arbiter12
body:
Ma dude... your innocence worries me so i will be harsh.

Do you really think, if the recipe for making money was "[just look for undervalued companies whereby their total share\*value is lower than their Ebitda/cashvalue!](https://corporatefinanceinstitute.com/resources/knowledge/trading-investing/trading-below-cash/)", professional trading houses would spend literal billions in research, algorithm and personnel?

&#x200B;

What you should first learn about this industry, if you want to succeed in it is that if something is easy and/or predictable, then it doesn't work/won't happen. You may get lucky and expect the expected and it happens just as planned, but most often, the big players are contrarian to the market itself, meaning that if you think A is likely and a million people think A is likely, then B is almost guaranteed to happen (unless enough contrarians think B will happen, then probably C)

Traders don't play the game fairly. They just harvest money from betting against the most number of people.

author: RumHam1
body:
Valuing a stock is really difficult and it often boils down to a lot of different assumptions.  Even experts are routinely wrong, so keep that in mind.  What I do for one company normally takes 3-5 hours, and I try to do it quarterly for any company I own.

I will usually start by collecting the company's past, current and future valuation metrics.  Things like price to sales, price to earnings, price to forward earnings, debt ratios, etc.  I compare the 5 year averages to what they currently are.  I also do for their competitors and companies in the same financial space (for example, I'd look at Visa, Mastercard, and other card companies together).  I look at past growth and projected growth to see if I think the valuations are justifiable where they currently are.

I look through the financial statements and try to spot trends in cash flow, debt, margin, and many other things to see how the company is performing yoy and qoq.

I look at how the company is engaging with the industry and where they are projecting their growth to come from.  Are the expanding market share, is the sector growing, etc.  I need the company to justify why it can achieve or surpass their growth estimates.

I listen to their most recent conference calls and look though any articles I can find, but I heavily discount opinion pieces.  I actively seek out reasons why this company will fail.

After all of this, I try to put together a balanced view of where the company is valued now vs historically and also vs their competition.  It requires a lot of projection and assumptions and I only do it for companies that I can understand their business model.  You have to go into the process without bias, and to be honest the majority of companies that I do this for aren't buys at the time.

author: Albedo100
body:
> Visa/Mastercard/Discover all charge the vendor a percentage of the transaction. This fee adds up. Blockchain can be substantially less.

Traditional transaction fees *can* be less as well if they just chose to lower the fees. 

You're missing the point that blockchains carry a premium cost to cover securing the network and it may never been competitive with closed systems. On blockchain *fees* are fundamental. In traditional systems, they aren't.

author: dontgetmadgetdata
body:
I like it. The price is pretty elevated off it’s 50 day MA due to a nice post earnings drift. It has kissed its 50 day 5 times this year. To increase your probability of profit, I might wait until it consolidates/retraces to around this area and open up the position at that time. Possibly move the strike closer to that stock price to further increase the leverage. 

For example, If it retraces to closer to $300 level and open contracts with $280-$300 strike. You would still need around $350 to break even if the cost is halved but you would have substantially more leverage per dollar.

author: Joltarts
body:
I paint you a highly probable bear scenario.

Tesla cant meet production demand because of microchip shortages. Tesla is the most chip dependant car company out there. They will get hit by a shortage in chips to produce their cars. The prices of chips will also shoot up so high, Tesla will have no choice but to sell their cars at even lesser margins.

The green credits which Tesla depends highly on to boost their profit numbers become less attractive in 2022 and it drops significantly. A big revenue stream for Tesla is about to go out of business.

Autonomous driving experiences set back, Tesla cant deliver a workable solution and regulations ban the use of fully auto vehicles due to safety concerns.

The already crowded Tesla network is both costly to maintain and cant expand quick enough. Other players using standard charging ports catch up and overtake Tesla here. Especially in Europe and China. Since Tesla cars can only charge on Tesla ports, suddenly, Tesla cars are less attractive to own.

author: eyerollingsex
body: Damn these MCHP lotto calls might pay 😤

author: jaedubbs
body:
Tesla has insane margins on their EVs and its clear that those margins are growing. The competition needs to sell 3+ EVs for every 1 that Tesla sells. And on top of that, Tesla produces cars in 1/3rd the time. Some OEMs are not profitable at all and each EV sold is a loss.

Also Tesla has car sales back logged for 6 months!

And a simple youtube search of FSD 10.3 shows dozens of reviews and drives of the general public. Meanwhile the competition only reveals company videos of their absolute best drives.

How about autonomous distribution?
How many self driving cars can the competition roll out to with these geofenced cars that need lidar and radar? Compare that to Tesla, which can push an over the air update and sell FSD to millions in an instant.

People keep calling Tesla just a car company, but what other car company is the:

Majority part Supplier
Dealership
Fuel provider
Microchip maker
AI developer
Software developer

author: spctr13
body:
> in fact im fairly certain all of our parts are manufactured on US soil

Down to what level though? Not many of the basic electronic components everything else is built from are made in the US. American companies like Vishay, Microchip, Texas Instruments, and Xilinx either operate factories in China or contract foundries in China or Taiwan. Other large supplies of ours are not even American such as Yageo and TE Connectivity aren't even headquartered in the US and manufacturer the bulk of their product in their home country. It's been a big issue for my portion of the defense industry the past couple of years because these factories in China are also sourcing a large portion of counterfeit electronic components on the market.

I know we're not the only defense manufacturer using Chinese components because I've seen several news articles and reports from the DOD claiming this is a problem.

https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2020/dec/10/us-military-reliance-china-foreign-suppliers-expos/

Panasonic and Murata (Japanese) used to produce critical components of our products, but have since stopped selling to us because they don't want their products used in munitions. When that happened the government fronted a lot of money to a couple American companies to produce an alternative since none existed.
